text: I'm dr. Emily Grossman welcome to cinema
science the show where we check out some
favorite films to see as the science
they contain is up to scratch this week
we're looking at explosions in space
if you're a fan of science fiction or
space movies you know probably caught
yourself looking forward to that epic
moment in movies such as Star Wars or
Ender's Game where the enemy spacecraft
is finally shot down exploding into a
massive fireball with an enormous boom
and sending debris flying out in all
directions
on earth explosions normally happen when
a material is subjected to a huge amount
of heat or pressure the heat and
pressure build up until there's a sudden
outburst if the gas is flammable it can
act as a fuel and the heat can be enough
to cause it to burst into flames
generating a massive fireball with the
accompanying pressure wave giving rise
to an enormous boom now if you remember
your fire triangle from school you'll be
familiar with the fact that fire needs
three ingredients fuel heat and oxygen
and it's this need for oxygen that
causes the problem in space the
gravitational attraction of large bodies
such as planets and stars pulls the gas
molecules in the air towards the surface
of these bodies leaving virtually none
behind in the vast spaces in between so
space is a vacuum a nearly total absence
of any gas molecules including that
all-important third ingredient oxygen in
the absence of oxygen fuels simply
cannot burn so a fireball in space
should be impossible however this is not
quite the case if the exploding aircraft
happened to contain liquid oxygen as
they often do this could be enough to
allow the hot gas to catch fire
producing a burst of light after a brief
moment the oxygen would be used up and
the fire would go out not exactly the
dramatic raging inferno that we see in
the movies another problem is the big
boom
when sound energy passes through a solid
liquid or gas it relies on the
vibrations of the particles making up
the medium the lack of air particles in
space means that sound waves simply
can't travel so any explosion would be
completely silent so the famous taglines
that alien is true in space no one can
hear you scream even the movies that get
space explosions nearly right tend to
miss one important detail in the movies
a spacecraft hurtling through the cosmos
usually stops dead in its tracks as it
explodes however in reality an exploding
spacecraft should continue moving
forward as there's no air resistance to
slow it down so next time we see a
spaceship exploding Star Trek we should
expect to see the remains traveling on
forever with the debris appearing in one
of the TV episodes 10 years later so
which films are closer to science fact
than science fiction well for all the
things it gets wrong this scene in
gravity does show a small explosion that
quickly dies out so we'll give it a
cinema science thumbs up what are your
favorite space explosions in movies let
us know in the comments below and don't
forget to hit subscribe for some more
great science from Brit nap
